column3: descript
How does the reasoning of one or both judges in this case reflect Locke's story about possession as the basis of property?

Is it correct to say that the court in Clift decides who owns the seals and who does not? Is it possible that both parties have legal entitlements to the seals, though one might receive priority over the other?
How might you characterize the styles of reasoning and argument employed by Judges Hoyles and Robinson in this case?
Do the judges styles of reasoning in this case more closely resemble that of Justice Dickson or Justice Laskin?
Is it possible to abandon wild seals once possession has established property rights in them? What steps if any would the sealers need to take?

How does Armorie v Delamirie complicate the link between possession and property that Locke is trying to establish? How is a "found" object similar to or diffferent from things in Locke's "state of nature"?
What are the necessary elements to a claim for possession and how do these play out differently in Armorie and in Keron v Cashman? How do they relate to the remedy?
Here the court finds that "possession is good title against all but the true owner". Can possession ever be good against the true owner themselves?
As you read the cases on adverse possession, consider how the Popov court's contextul approach to determining physical control in possessory claims affects the analysis.
Does Justice McCarthy's analysis accord with a Lockean view of first possession?
What is required for a claimant to successfully make out a claim to adverse possession?

The majority in the Annapolis decision claim that they have clarified, but not changed, the test for constructive expropriation from CPR. Is this an accurate claim? Would the City of Vancouver in CPR be found to have gained an "advantage" according to the majority's view in Annapolis?

How does the majority in Annapolis (citing De Keyser's Royal Hotel) draw on the principle of statutory interpretation articulated by the Supreme Court in McLaren v Caldwell? Does it alter this principle in any way?

Justice Middleton cites the Shelfer case in discussing the court's discretion on the issue of remedy. What legal framework does the Shelfer provide and how is it applied by the court in Black v Canadian Copper?
The facts here seem similar in many respects to those in Canada Paper Co v Brown. Why do the courts reach different conclusions on the issue of remedy?
At least one judge in this case cites the Shelfer decision. What legal framework does Shelfer provide and how is it applied, if at all, by the judges in Canada Paper v Brown?
The facts here seem similar in many respects to those in Black v Canadian Copper Co. Why do the courts reach different conclusions on the issue of remedy?
Does the Court in McCorkill extend the public policy doctrine expressed by the court in Canada Trust?
While Re Drummond Wren deals with a restrictive covenant, is the doctrine expressed in that case the same or similar to the one described here? How?
Is the finding in Cappy consistent with the Supreme Court's test for acquired rights estblished in Saint-Romuald?
In the Annapolis case, the Supreme Court further "clarifies" the emerging test for de facto expropriation established in CPR. Is that clarified test consistent with the result in CPR on its facts?
In Tsilhqot'in, the Supreme Court continued to develop the framework established in Delgamuukw, resulting in the first successful claim in an Anglo-Canadian court.
On similar facts, Noble and Wolfe v Alley comes before the Ontario Court of Appeal just a few years later. Does the Court follow Re Drummond Wren? Why or why not?
Notice that the judge here does not cite Tulk v Moxhay but rather focuses heavily on the statutory context. Is there a reason for this?
Why does the potential restraint on alienation in this case not fall within the potential exceptions discussed in Blackburn?
In Adams and Stanger-Ross' view, how should the obligations of the trustee of Japanese Canadians' property be conceived? Are these consistent with the characterization in Duthie?
What has changed with respect to the common law doctrine of Aboriginal title between St Cahterine's Milling and Guerin?
The fiduciary duty identified in Guerin has been an important basis for the Crown's obligations in dealing with reserve lands under the federal Indian Act.
How do the judges' definitions of "possession" in this case affect the interpretation of the Protection of Property Act?

The authors in this excerpt disagree with the court's conclusion in Iwasaki related to the characterization of a trust and breach of that trust. What aspects of the Orders in Council issued are important for making that argument?

Nowhere is the Iwasaki decision does the plaintiff claim or the court discuss the idea that the Canadian government expropriated the property of Japanese Canadians. Why do you think such a claim was omitted?
The Ontario Court of Appeal in Keefer builds on the legal framework that is early developed in Piper. What is the test for adverse possession that emerges from the Court of Appeal's analysis?
How does the law of adverse possession differ with respect to private and public land?

On the facts, the parties in this dispute agreed that a prima facie case for adverse possession had been made out by the private landowners. Consider how each of the elements of a claim to adverse possession as established in Keefer have been satisfied here.
What is the basic legal principle, sometimes expressed as "finders keepers", at work in this case? Where is that princple found in Armorie v Delamirie?
What does Locke mean by the "state of nature"? Do you think he means the same thing as the "state of nature" identified in the Wildlife Act?
In his story, Locke's idea about how one establishes possession as the basis of property is portrayed as self-evident. Does this hold true when applied to the facts of Pierson v Post?
In what way does the approach to possession in Armorie v Delamairie complicate the story about possession and ownership told by Locke?
How does Justice Cromwell's decision in Mariner fill in the interpretive "gaps" in Nova Scotia's expropriation statute in cases of constructive takings?
In this case, the Supreme Court picks up on the analysis in Mariner as the basis for a new test in cases of constructive expropriation. Does it reach the right result?
In what ways is Justice Cromwell's decision in this case consistent or inconsistent with the modern style of Anglo-Canadian legal thought?

The Ontario Court of Appeal in Canada Trust addresses the same broad question of whether and how Anglo-Canadian property law can confront attempts by owners to control their property toward discriminatory ends. How does the Court of Appeal's approach to this question differ from the Supreme Court in Noble v Alley?
The court in Black v Canadian Copper Co appears to apply the test in Shelfer. What does it conclude?
The court in Canada Paper Co v Brown applies the test in Shelfer. What does it conclude?
What role does the concept of the Crown's allodial title play in St. Catherine's Milling? Is Aboriginal Title, as conceived here, related to the idea of the fee simple estate?
In what way, if any, is Locke's theory about possession as the basis of property relevant to the courts' reasons in St. Catherine's Milling?

What is the relationship between the treaty rights of a Mi'kmaw hunter and provincial legislation that regulates hunting wildlife? Are treaty rights about "ownership" of wild animals or something different?
The idea that Anglo-Canadian law is paramount plays a key role in the Court's reasoning. How is this connected to the doctrine of terra nullius?
Can you envision an alternative approach to resolving this case that refers to or relies on the concept of Netukulimk? How might this reasoning work?
The concept of abandonment--both in general and with respect to wild animals--is discussed as some length in this case.
In what ways does the court in Bamberger affirm the findings in Victoria (City)? In what way does it diverge or extend these findings?

Subsequent decisions, including the court's in Heegsma, have reflected on the approach taken in Bamberger and its feasibility. Consider to what extent this is a consequence of the path chartered back in Victoria (City).
What features of the classical style are apparent in each of the judgments in Victoria Park? How do the underlying assumptions of the style drive the disagreements between the judges?
This short excerpt will give you a better understand of the basic concepts at play in the Walker case.
Both Walker and Blackburn address the idea of "restraints on alienation". Are such restraints ever allowed, and if so, when?
Can you identify one or more of the different interests described in the current excerpt in Re Walker?
How does the testamentary bequest in Blackburn constructed using the interests described in this excerpt?
How does Professor Henderson's interpretation of the 1752 Treaty open the way for application of Netukulimk and other Mi'kmaw legal concepts?
While not mentioned by name, the doctrine of terra nullius looms large in the Syliboy case. How is it significant for the court's reasoning?
What exactly do the obligations of a trustee look like? To whom are those obligations owed?

In this case, the claimant argues that orders in council passed pursuant to the War Measures Act created a trust and that the federal appointees responsible for the property of Japanese-Canadians acted in breach of that trust.

The authors in this excerpt argue that the concept of a "trust" should have been applied to analyze the federal government's treatment of Japanese Canadians' property. How might the different components of a trust be mapped onto this context?
The conclusion put forward here by Adams and Stranger-Ross regarding the role of trusts in the dispossession of Japanese Canadians is rejected by the court in Iwasaki. Why?
The members of the House of Commons in this excerpt are debating the question of whether or not to "disallow" Ontario's legislation intervening in the McLaren v Caldwell dispute.
How do the arguments related to expropriation compare to the posittions of the judges in Pennsylvania Coal v Mahon?
How do the rules of interpretation in the Wills Act and the Conveyancing Act differ? Do these difference matter?

The Mariner case was the first contemporary appeals court decision that attempted to interpret Nova Scotia's Expropriation Act in a case of de facto expropriation. In doing so, the Court establishes a framework for analysis. What is the legal "test" for de facto expropriation that emerges from the case and how does this motivated by the modern style?
How do these provisions of the federal Indian Act reflect the concepts of beneficial title and underlying or radical title discussed in St. Catherine's Milling?
The Supreme Court in Guerin elaborates the fiduciary relationship between Indigenous peoples and the Crown. What are the implications of this relationship for reserve lands?
Which aspects of this legislation are supplanted for First Nations under the Framework Agreement on First Nations Land Management Act?
How do we know if some change to an existing non-conforming use causes the owner to lose the protections afforded by the doctrine of acquired rights?
What is the relevance of "possession" in the Protection of Property Act? Does the Act tell us what this means? Does the decision in Harrison v Carswell?

After Ontario passed this legislation in 1881, the issue came before the federal parliament as to whether it should 'disallow' the statue. Consider these excerpts from the parliamentary debates (Hansard) between opposing political parties for what they tell us about how this statute and the McLaren case relate to the issue of expropriation.
To what extent is the Royal Proclamation based on the structure of feudal land tenure? What assumptions are at play here?

What roles does the Royal Proclamation play in the courts' reasoning in the St. Catherine's Milling case? Is the Proclamation understood as a source of Indigenous rights in land, a recognition of those rights, or something else? What features of Aboriginal Title, from the common law perspective, does the Proclamation describe?
The statute here refers to a "state of nature". What role does this "state of nature" play in Locke's theory of possession as the basis for property? Are these meanings the same?
How should we understand the application of the Wildlife Act in circumstances where Mi'kmaq are exercising their treaty rights?
How do the rules of interpretation in the Wills Act and the Conveyancing Act differ? Do these difference matter?
How is the type of property (public/private) at issue here different or the same as property in Harrison v Carswell? Why does this matter?
How is the type of property (public/private) at issue here different or the same as property in the Committee for the Commonwealth case?  Why does this matter for our weekyl problem?
How does Locke's theory of posession and property underlie the reasoning (of both judges) in this case?
Are there alternative resolutions to this dispute that the judges fail to consider? For example, how might the resolution in Keron v Cashman apply?

There appears to be a tension, if not outright disagreement, about the legal role and significance of the 1752 Treaty between the Court in R v Simon and Professor Henderson's description. What is this disagreement?
How should we understand the application of the Wildlife Act in circumstances where Mi'kmaq are exercising their treaty rights?

Would Professor Henderson agree or disagree with the Court's treatment of the 1752 Treaty in Simon? Where does Professor Henerson differ from the Court in how he urges us to think about the nature of this and other treaties?
Some of the legal concepts of Mi'kmaw land tenure introduced here are elaborated by Professor Battiste in this excerpt on netukulimk.

How does the structure of feudal land tenure set the context for the courts' reasoning in the St. Catherine's Milling case? What assumptions are necessary to apply the medieval setting here to that of North America?
How do the different judges competing views about the Royal Proclamation, 1763 shape their decisions and their understand of the source and nature of Aboriginal Title?

As we will study later in the course, section 35 has been interpreted by the courts as  applying to the recognition of Aboriginal Title, i.e. Indigenous rights in land. While St. Catherine's Milling precedes the use of this term, the decisions in this case provide an early window into how the concept was understood in the common law courts.
How does Locke's theory of possession and property relate to the legal issue in the St. Catherine's Milling case? Does Locke provide a justification for the judges' reasons?
Why does Lord Brougham decline to enforce the covenant against the new owners of the ironworks? What distinguishes this case from Tulk v Moxhay in which the court reaches a different outcome?
If the covenant in Tulk v Moxhay is found to be enforceable in equity against a downstream purchaser, why was the covenant in Keppell v Bailey unenforceable?

What obligations or restrictions does the covenant in Tulk v Moxhay impose on the owner of Leichester Square? How do those obligations or restrictions differ from those at issue in Austerberry v Oldham Corp? In what way do these differences determine the enforceability of the covenant?

There are two key differences in the facts with respect to the covenant at issue in this case compared to the one in Tulk v Moxhay. Can you identify these differences and explain how they relate ot the outcome in the case?
Review this short section on water rights as background to the courts' findings in McLaren v Caldwell.
These principles are applied in McLaren v Caldwell to determine the status of McLaren's riparian rights.
Compare the competing posittions of Justice Holmes and Justice Brandeis to the House of Commons debates in the course of the McLaren v Caldwell saga.
How does the principles of statutory interpretation idenfieid by the Supreme Court in McLaren get develop and applied in the Manitoba Fisheries case?
How does the Supreme Court in this case build on the approach to expropriation taken in McLaren v Caldwell?
The House of Commons debates excerpted here address the question of expropriation and the legislature's proper role in the McLaren v Caldwell saga.
Why do the House members in this excerpt disagree with one another on the issue of expropriation, and what is the proper role of the legislature here vis-à-vis the courts?
Both Walker and Blackburn address the idea of "restraints on alienation". Are such restraints ever allowed, and if so, when?
